rIGLIx-y6.memHandModelNotes: Florida GAP has this species in urban and residential areas, while SC and GA do not.  NatureServe notes that urbanized areas are a separation barrier between occurrences and populations.  It may be that a model would select urban and residential only in FL, but this seems unlikely from a biological perspective.  I left the developed map units unselected until further review.  I was also not sure how to handle the "marsh edge habitats" referred to in both Wilson and NatureServe write-ups.  It may be that a buffer on marshes would provide additional habitat to those xeric pine flatwoods and maritme forest map units.
